From: "Ken Lloyd" <kalloyd@...>
Subject: RE: [neat] Re: Ken's Question to Dawkins, Wolpert, and Jones at GECCO 2007
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=37465196; y=aP_64mpchw-fy2JCaCkpwTaALjhcj3m28VMCh8MZ4c2jkmQ

------=_NextPart_000_005C_01C85363.7B1E2520
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

It was interesting to me how these intelligent, learned men framed the
question - more correctly they missed the salient intent of the question -
therefore misframed the question when constructing their answers.  This was
as fascinating as it was often.
 
A phenomenon akin to tunnel-vision sometimes sets in in the minds of
"experts" where the context of their expertise rejects or transforms the
query into something more palatable to their context.  I see this often in
my work.  The fact that this tendency is reduced by starting de novo or
minimally is one of the particular strengths in neuro-evolution.
 
Learning to use these tools teaches us something not only about the tools,
but ourselves.
 
Ken Lloyd


  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Kenneth Stanley
Sent: Friday, January 04, 2008 7:47 PM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [neat] Re: Ken's Question to Dawkins, Wolpert, and Jones at GECCO
2007



I should clarify that I did not expect to get a definitive answer 
from anyone when I asked the question. As Dr. Jones stated up front, 
no one knows the full answer, and that's absolutely true. What I was 
more interested in was how the leaders in these areas of biology 
think about this issue, which I see as one of the most profound 
puzzles at the core of evolution, whether natural or artificial. 
Thus, it is intriguing to learn the depth of insight that they can 
draw from their respective realms of expertise.

So when I express disappointment over the answers, it is not because 
they failed to solve the entire problem. Rather, it is that the 
answers were mainly superficial and perhaps even touching on the 
obvious (of course to a GECCO audience what is obvious is quite 
different than to a normal audience). It left me feeling that, at 
least within their spheres of research, the puzzles of complexity are 
seen more as peripheral curiosities than paradigm-defining problems. 
While it is certainly possible that they have deeper insights than 
those they offered, it seems a bit strange that they would fail to 
share them at a debate headlined as "evolution and complexity" in 
front of an audience of Ph.D. scientists. So it's not unreasonable 
to conclude they don't have a lot to say on the subject that is 
particularly groundbreaking.

If that is true, my view is that it is somewhat unfortunate for 
biology. So while their answers perhaps reflect the best the field 
has to offer (as Thomas speculates may be the case), the field in 
that case must bear the burden of ignoring such important issues. By 
the way, I know that some biologists such as Raff and Meinhardt probe 
these issues much deeper than this panel did, so I would not naively 
endict the entire field. But the mainstream seems a bit off the 
track. 

What's really interesting about all this, from a GECCO point of view, 
is that it may be that evolutionary computation, rather than biology, 
is where some of the most powerful secrets of evolution are beginning 
to fall out. Who would have thought? 

Most people at GECCO who I spoke to after the debate echoed the 
sentiment that they hadn't really learned much, and in fact, had 
heard deeper insights on evolution and complexity during GDS-track 
(Generative and Developmental Systems, a track at GECCO) paper talks 
than during the keynote event.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com, "Thomas
Johnson" <thomas.j.johnson@...> 
wrote:
>
> These people must have email addresses, why not follow up with them 
that
> way? If they care about the question at all, I'm sure they'll give 
a more
> thoughtful response via email. If they don't care, well, then 
that's why you
> got such bad answers in the first place :-)
> 
> Or, maybe you got bad answers because the answers actually reflect 
the
> current best guesses in their fields. In that case, the answers 
aren't
> really bad, it's just that people in other fields haven't been 
focusing
> their attention on this problem.
> 
> Tom
> 
> On Jan 4, 2008 12:09 AM, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> 
> > Yes, the answers were indeed lacking. By the way, notice also 
how
> > they ignored the second part of my question: "How can evolution
> > search a space of such astronomical complexity?"
> >
> > I was really disappointed that they didn't even venture into that
> > issue, because that's the really interesting question. Of course 
you
> > can always speculate on how a little can be converted to a lot by
> > talking about fractals and subroutines (after all, that's just
> > compression), but when you realize that we are talking about
> > *searching* a space of such mappings, it becomes far more 
complicated
> > and profound. The problem then becomes compounded by the fact that
> > not only must the representation be efficient but it must also 
warp
> > in meaningful ways, e.g. a biped should have biped children. How
> > does natural evolution manage to induce such a nicely structured
> > search space? Not a word was said on the matter.
> >
> > ken
> >
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com <neat%
40yahoogroups.com>, "petar_chervenski"
> >
> > <petar_chervenski@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Well, after I saw the video.. I don't know these people, they
> > should
> > > be very good scientists, but.. Their answers.. Sucked! Sorry 
about
> > > that language, but.. At least from my point of view, the answer
> > that
> > > DNA holds much more information seems the closest to the truth 
to
> > me.
> > > The composition of subroutines may bring a lot of complexity, 
but
> > not
> > > as close as this in nature, which was the question itself! In 
fact
> > we
> > > already know that..
> > > Hah, they even couldn't complete their answer, someone's wife 
just
> > > called.. They had to be more interested on this issue.
> > >
> > >
> > > --- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com
<neat%40yahoogroups.com>, "Derek 
James"
> > <djames@> wrote:
> > > >
> > > > Update: I asked Peter Bentley if it would be all right to 
upload
> > the
> > > > video to Google Video, and he said yes, as long as I linked 
back
> > to
> > > > his site and didn't edit it in any way. I didn't see a reason 
why
> > it
> > > > shouldn't be available as streaming video, since it's the 
venues
> > > exist
> > > > and it's a pain to download the torrent. Anyway, the link is 
here:
> > > >
> > > > http://video. <http://video.google.com/videoplay?>
google.com/videoplay?
docid=3201752343509862659&hl=en
> > > >
> > > > Ken's question is at 59:21 in the video.
> > > >
> > > > On Jan 2, 2008 12:58 AM, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@> wrote:
> > > > >
> > > > > Hi Derek, I had forgotten that they recorded that debate. I
> > > enjoyed
> > > > > having the opportunity to ask my question to such 
illustrious
> > > > > scientists, but like you, I was kind of disappointed with 
their
> > > > > answers. Like you said, they sort of answered accurately, 
but
> > > there
> > > > > was no real insight or thoughtfulness in what they said.
> > > > >
> > > > > It's interesting that you point out this exchange because I
> > > think it
> > > > > highlights a weakness in how biologists have been dealing 
with
> > > the
> > > > > question of complexity. It's such a fundamental question 
yet it
> > > > > hasn't really received the treatment it deserves, even from 
the
> > > > > field's luminaries. I think part of the problem is that a
> > genuine
> > > > > treatment requires a kind of algorithmic and 
representational
> > > theory,
> > > > > which is perhaps better attacked from a computational
> > > perspective,
> > > > > putting evolutionary computation researchers at an advantage
> > > because
> > > > > we think about search spaces, encodings, mappings, etc.
> > > routinely.
> > > >
> > > > Yes, I think you're right that EC researcher probably come at 
the
> > > > problem from an angle that might be more productive, but I'm
> > > > especially disappointed in Wolpert, who was the main voice for
> > > > developmental biology on the panel. Your question gets to 
issues
> > > that
> > > > a developmental biologist should primarily be interested in.
> > > >
> > > > Even if he didn't have specific insights related to the
> > development
> > > of
> > > > the human brain, he should have been able to give other 
examples
> > > with
> > > > which he was more familiar.
> > > >
> > > > By the way, I recently read Pasko Rakic's 1995 paper "A small
> > step
> > > for
> > > > the cell, a giant leap for mankind: a hypothesis of 
neocortical
> > > > expansion during evolution" from Trends in Neuroscience:
> > > >
> > > > http://www.scienced <http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?>
irect.com/science?
_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6T0V-
> > > 3Y6PFXS-
> > >
> > 
1P&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&view=c&_acct=C000050221
> > >
> > 
&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=4eba37dec70f1bb0d9022402f97ae
> > > e43
> > > >
> > > > Here's the abstract:
> > > >
> > > > The more than 1000-fold increase in the cortical surface 
without a
> > > > comparable increase in its thickness during mammalian 
evolution is
> > > > explained in the context of the radial-unit hypothesis of 
cortical
> > > > development. According to the proposed model, cortical 
expansion
> > is
> > > > the result of changes in proliferation kinetics that increase 
the
> > > > number of radial columnar units without changing the number of
> > > neurons
> > > > within each unit significantly. Thus, mutation of a regulatory
> > gene
> > > (s)
> > > > that controls the timing and ratio of symmetric and asymmetric
> > modes
> > > > of cell divisions in the proliferative zone, coupled with 
radial
> > > > constraints in the distribution of migrating neurons, could
> > create
> > > an
> > > > expanded cortical plate with enhanced capacity for 
establishing
> > new
> > > > patterns of connectivity that are validated through natural
> > > selection.
> > > >
> > > > I'm personally working under the assumption that the cortical
> > > > minicolumn is the primary module, that repeatable bit of code 
that
> > > > Dawkins talked about, and there are a number of good work by
> > > > biologists out there, including Rakic, who give support to 
such an
> > > > idea.
> > > >
> > > > > Perhaps they were just being curt or did not take the 
audience
> > > > > seriously enough to elaborate their thoughts. Yet I find 
that
> > > > > explanation doubtful given that we were after all at
> > a "debate"
> > > about
> > > > > evolution and complexity, which is precisely the substance 
of
> > my
> > > > > question. I also agree that Dawkins seemed closest to really
> > > > > thinking about it, so I'd guess Dawkins would be very
> > interested
> > > in
> > > > > our area of EC if only there was an opportunity to tell him
> > about
> > > > > it. But I don't think he has a great deal of experience 
with it
> > > > > beyond his old Blind Watchmaker demo.
> > > >
> > > > I guess you didn't have a chance to corner him and talk things
> > over?
> > > > :) Dawkins does seem like he would be interested in a lot of 
the
> > > work
> > > > being presented at GECCO. Did he just show up for the panel, 
or
> > was
> > > he
> > > > around the conference at all?
> > > >
> > > > I was also thought the other really interesting exchange was 
at
> > > 33:45
> > > > in the video, when the question of whether or not you could
> > evolve a
> > > > mouse with feathered wings came up, and Wolpert and Jones both
> > said
> > > > no, while Dawkins seemed to say probably not, but not for any 
of
> > the
> > > > reasons the other guys came up with.
> > > >
> > > > --Derek
> > > >
> > >
> >
> > 
> >
>
